name: Hangboard Repeaters (7s on / 3s off)
summary: Classic repeaters for finger endurance/power endurance.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Build finger **power endurance** by repeating sub-maximal hangs with short recoveries.

## Setup
- Choose an edge/hold you can complete for the full set **with good form** (typically ~60–80% effort).
- Use a **half crimp or open-hand** grip unless your plan specifies otherwise.
- Start every hang from **engaged shoulders** (scapula slightly down/back), elbows straight.

## How to do it
1. Hang for **7s**.
2. Rest for **3s** (stay close to the board; shake out).
3. Repeat for **6 reps** to complete a set.
4. Rest **3–4 min** between sets.
5. Complete **3 sets**.

## Intensity & progression
- Aim to finish each set with **1–2 reps in reserve** (no “fight to failure”).
- Progress by: slightly smaller edge, adding small weight, or adding a set (not all at once).

## Safety
- Stop if you feel **sharp finger pain** or pulley tenderness.
- Keep wrists neutral; avoid “chicken-wing” shoulders.
cues: Shoulders engaged: scapula down/back, ribs stacked.
Quiet, controlled start—no bouncing into the hang.
Use the same grip depth each rep (consistent edge contact).
Breathe: short inhale on, exhale during the hang.
End reps cleanly—step down before form breaks.
commonMistakes: Choosing an edge that forces failure before the last reps.
Shrugging shoulders up into ears during fatigue.
Letting elbows bend to ‘cheat’ the hang.
Switching grip mid-set (open-hand → crimp) without intent.
Skipping warm-up or starting repeaters cold.

name: Hangboard Repeaters (6s on / 4s off)
summary: Repeaters variant with slightly more recovery per rep.
instructionsMarkdown:

2. Rest for **4s** (stay close to the board; shake out).
3. Repeat for **6 reps** to complete a set.
4. Rest **3–4 min** between sets.
5. Complete **3 sets**.

## Intensity & progression

- Progress by: slightly smaller edge, adding small weight, or adding a set (not all at once).

## Safety
- Stop if you feel **sharp finger pain** or pulley tenderness.
- Keep wrists neutral; avoid “chicken-wing” shoulders.

name: Hangboard Repeaters (10s on / 5s off)

## Setup
- Choose an edge/hold you can complete for the full set **with good form** (typically ~60–80% effort).

1. Hang for **10s**.
2. Rest for **5s** (stay close to the board; shake out).
3. Repeat for **5 reps** to complete a set.
4. Rest **4–5 min** between sets.
5. Complete **3 sets**.

## Intensity & progression
- Aim to finish each set with **1–2 reps in reserve** (no “fight to failure”).
- Progress by: slightly smaller edge, adding small weight, or adding a set (not all at once).

## Safety
- Stop if you feel **sharp finger pain** or pulley tenderness.
- Keep wrists neutral; avoid “chicken-wing” shoulders.

name: Max Hang (10s) — Open Hand
summary: Max strength finger hang using open-hand grip.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Increase **max finger strength** with heavy, low-volume hangs in a open-hand position.

## Setup
- Select an edge where **10s is hard but repeatable** with added weight or assistance.
- Use a **timer** and consistent grip depth.
- Warm up thoroughly: easy hangs → a few progressively harder singles.

## How to do it
1. Get into position: shoulders engaged, elbows straight, wrists neutral.
2. Hang for **10s** at **near-max** effort (aim ~RPE 9–9.5).
3. Rest **3 min** between hangs.
4. Complete **5 total hangs**.

## Load guidance
- If you can exceed 10s with control, **add small weight** (1–2 kg) or use a smaller edge.
- If you fail early (<8s), **reduce load** or increase edge size.

## Safety
- Avoid full crimp unless specifically programmed and you tolerate it well.
- Stop if you feel sharp pain, a “pop,” or lingering soreness that changes how you grip.
cues: Start from dead still—no kick or swing.
Engage lats: ‘pull shoulder blades into back pockets.’
Neutral wrist; squeeze through fingertip pads, not knuckles.
Hold open-hand: keep finger position consistent the entire hang.
Step down before the hang becomes a fight.
commonMistakes: Grinding to failure on every set (too much strain, poor recovery).
Shrugging or bending elbows to extend time.
Inconsistent edge depth between sets.
Rushing rest periods (reduces quality of max-strength stimulus).
Ignoring skin/finger warning signs.

name: Max Hang (10s) — Half Crimp
summary: Max strength finger hang using half-crimp grip.
instructionsMarkdown:

Increase **max finger strength** with heavy, low-volume hangs in a half crimp position.

- Select an edge where **10s is hard but repeatable** with added weight or assistance.

## Safety

- Stop if you feel sharp pain, a “pop,” or lingering soreness that changes how you grip.

name: Density Hangs (30s on / 30s off)
summary: Sub-max finger density work; control intensity and volume.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Build **sub-max finger capacity** (density) with controlled intensity and steady volume.

## Setup
- Choose an edge/hold that feels **moderate** (you should never be close to failure).
- Use open-hand or half-crimp; keep it consistent.
- Track total volume: density work accumulates fast.

## How to do it
1. Hang for **30s**.
2. Rest for **30s**.
3. Repeat for **10 reps** to complete a set.
4. Rest **4–5 min** between sets.
5. Complete **2 sets**.

## Intensity target
- Aim for a “working pump” but **no form breakdown** and no pain.
- If your forearms are exploding early, the edge is too small or you need assistance.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders engaged and wrists neutral.
- Avoid density hangs if you have active finger tweaky pain.
cues: Smooth, relaxed breathing—don’t hold your breath.
Shoulders stable; forearms do the work.
Same grip depth every rep.
Shake out during rests; stay tall through the torso.
commonMistakes: Treating density like repeaters and going too hard.
Letting shoulders shrug as fatigue builds.
Continuing through finger pain or pulley tenderness.
Adding volume too quickly week-to-week.

name: Assisted One-Arm Hangs
summary: Progression toward one-arm hanging using assistance (pulley/band).
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Progress toward **one-arm hanging strength** while keeping the elbow and shoulder safe using assistance.

## Setup
- Use a pulley/counterweight or band so the working arm can hold **clean form**.
- Choose a comfortable edge; do not chase tiny holds here.
- Keep assistance consistent across reps so you can track progress.

## How to do it
1. Set up assistance (pulley or band) so the off-hand reduces load.
2. Hang mostly on the working arm for **7s**.
3. Rest **45s**, then repeat for **3 reps** on that side.
4. Switch sides and repeat.
5. Rest **3 min** between sets; complete **3 sets**.

## Intensity & progression
- Effort should feel **hard but controlled** (no twisting, no elbow flare).
- Progress by: reducing assistance slightly, increasing hold time, or adding a rep.

## Safety
- Avoid deep shoulder internal rotation; keep chest proud and scapula engaged.
- If you get medial elbow pain, stop and reduce intensity/volume next time.
cues: Square hips and shoulders—don’t twist to ‘cheat’ the hang.
Keep scapula set: down/back, not shrugged.
Wrist neutral; grip through fingertip pads.
Use just enough assistance to keep the rep smooth.
Switch sides with equal total volume.
commonMistakes: Using too little assistance and compensating with twisting.
Letting the working shoulder ride up.
Hanging with a bent elbow to ‘save’ fingers.
Going to failure and irritating the elbow.
Uneven volume between left/right.

name: Recruitment Pulls (Hangboard)
summary: Short explosive pulls to recruit high-threshold motor units (low volume).
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Recruit high-threshold pulling + finger units with **very short, explosive** efforts (low fatigue).

## Setup
- Use a comfortable edge (or large rung) and ensure you can stay controlled.
- Warm up thoroughly; do a few easy explosive pulls before starting.
- Keep total volume low; quality over quantity.

## How to do it
1. From a dead hang with engaged shoulders, perform an **explosive pull** (1–2 seconds).
2. Return under control to the start position.
3. Repeat for **3 reps**.
4. Rest **3 min** and repeat for **5 sets**.

## Intensity
- Each rep should feel **snappy**; stop the set if speed drops.
- This is not conditioning—avoid accumulating pump.

## Safety
- Do not do recruitment pulls when fingers are sore or skin is thin.
- Keep elbows tracking naturally; avoid painful ‘tweaks’.
cues: Explode up, control down—no slam or drop.
Stop a set as soon as speed fades.
Engage shoulders before the first pull.
Keep core tight to minimize swinging.
Use a grip you can keep consistent.
commonMistakes: Turning it into a high-rep workout and getting pumped.
Using an edge that’s too small and loading fingers aggressively.
Dropping into the bottom and bouncing into the next rep.
Ignoring elbow discomfort or ‘tendon-y’ sensations.
Doing recruitment work when already fatigued.

name: Foot-on-Campus Assisted Hangs
summary: Technique-safe way to scale intensity using feet on rungs/box.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Scale hangboard intensity using your feet so you can build volume safely.

## Setup
- Put one or both feet on a box/rung so you can **reduce finger load**.
- Keep shoulders engaged and minimize swing.
- Adjust foot pressure so the last reps are challenging but controlled.

## How to do it
1. Start in a stable position with feet lightly weighted.
2. Hang for **7s**, then rest **3s** (maintain position).
3. Repeat for **6 reps**.
4. Rest **3 min** between sets; do **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Reduce foot assistance over time (lighter feet), or use a slightly smaller edge.

## Safety
- Avoid sudden unloading/loading through the feet; keep pressure consistent.
cues: Press feet consistently—don’t ‘step on’ only when tired.
Shoulders set; long neck, chest tall.
Minimal swing; keep hips under the board.
Use the same grip and edge contact each rep.
commonMistakes: Too much assistance (exercise becomes too easy).
Too little assistance (form breaks or fingers strain).
Letting shoulders shrug when tired.
Changing foot position mid-set and losing consistency.

name: Finger Extensor Band Opens
summary: Finger extensor work to balance gripping volume.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Train finger extensors to balance high gripping volume and support elbow/forearm health.

## Setup
- Place finger bands around fingertips (not the knuckles).
- Use a resistance that lets you open fully without pain.

## How to do it
1. Start with fingers together and slightly bent.
2. Open fingers against the band until fully extended.
3. Control back to the start (don’t snap shut).
4. Perform **25 reps** for **3 sets**, resting **60s** between sets.

## Progression
- Increase reps first, then add slightly stronger bands.

## Safety
- Keep movement pain-free; stop if you feel sharp pain on the outside of the elbow.
cues: Open all fingers evenly (don’t let pinky lag).
Slow return—control the eccentric.
Keep wrist neutral.
Work for a light burn, not a cramp.
commonMistakes: Using a band that’s too strong and losing range of motion.
Letting the band ride down toward the knuckles.
Snapping fingers closed between reps.
Shrugging shoulders or tensing the neck.

name: Weighted Pull-Ups
summary: Upper-body pulling strength base for climbing.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Upper-body pulling strength base for climbing.

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **3–6**.
- Use a weight belt or dumbbell; keep it strict.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **3–3 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 6; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
- If elbows feel irritated, reduce load and keep reps slower.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.
Keep ribs down and core braced.
Shoulders away from ears throughout.
Move smoothly—no bouncing or kipping unless intended.
commonMistakes: Chasing reps with ugly form.
Letting shoulders roll forward at the top/bottom.
Cutting range of motion as fatigue builds.
Not resting enough to keep reps high quality.

name: Pull-Ups (Bodyweight)
summary: Fundamental pulling strength; strict reps.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Fundamental strict pulling strength with clean scap control.

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **5–10**.
- Use assistance (band) if you can’t keep full range.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **2–3 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 10; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
- Avoid kipping unless specifically training it.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.
Keep ribs down and core braced.
Shoulders away from ears throughout.
Move smoothly—no bouncing or kipping unless intended.

Not resting enough to keep reps high quality.

name: Scapular Pull-Ups
summary: Scap control for shoulder health and pulling efficiency.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Scapular depression/retraction strength for shoulder health and efficient pulling.

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **8–15**.
- Arms stay straight; movement comes from the shoulder blades.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **1–2 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 15; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
- Keep it small and controlled—no jerking.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.
Keep ribs down and core braced.
Shoulders away from ears throughout.
Move smoothly—no bouncing or kipping unless intended.
commonMistakes: Chasing reps with ugly form.
Letting shoulders roll forward at the top/bottom.
Cutting range of motion as fatigue builds.
Not resting enough to keep reps high quality.

name: Lock-Off Holds (90°)
summary: Isometric lock-offs for control on steep terrain.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Isometric lock-off strength and control around ~90° elbow angle.

## Setup
- Use a position you can hold with **no joint pain**.
- Keep shoulders engaged and core tight.

## How to do it
1. Get into the target position.
2. Hold for **10s** with steady breathing.
3. Rest **2–2 min**.
4. Complete **5 holds**.

## Progression
- Increase hold time first, then move to a harder progression.

## Safety
- Stop if you feel sharp pain in the shoulder, elbow, or lower back.
cues: Breathe—avoid breath-holding.
Maintain body tension (ribs down, glutes on).
Keep shoulder blades engaged and stable.
Stop the set before you lose the shape.
commonMistakes: Overarching lower back to ‘fake’ the position.
Shrugging into shoulders during fatigue.
Holding too long and turning it into a sloppy grind.
Progressing too quickly to harder variations.

name: Lock-Off Holds (120°)
summary: Longer lever lock-offs; scalable difficulty.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Isometric lock-off strength around ~120° elbow angle (more extended).

## Setup
- Use a position you can hold with **no joint pain**.
- Keep shoulders engaged and core tight.

## How to do it
1. Get into the target position.
2. Hold for **10s** with steady breathing.
3. Rest **2–2 min**.
4. Complete **5 holds**.

## Progression
- Increase hold time first, then move to a harder progression.

## Safety
- Stop if you feel sharp pain in the shoulder, elbow, or lower back.
cues: Breathe—avoid breath-holding.
Maintain body tension (ribs down, glutes on).
Keep shoulder blades engaged and stable.
Stop the set before you lose the shape.

name: Towel Pull-Ups
summary: Grip + pulling strength; use carefully for skin/elbows.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Grip-focused pulling strength (more forearm + elbow demand).

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **3–6**.
- Drape two towels over the bar or use one thick towel for more difficulty.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **3–3 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 6; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
- Be conservative if you’re prone to medial elbow pain.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.

name: Ring Rows
summary: Scalable horizontal pulling; shoulder-friendly.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Scalable horizontal pulling for upper-back strength and shoulder balance.

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **8–15**.
- Walk feet forward to make it harder; keep body in a straight line.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **2–2 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 15; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
- Avoid shrugging at the top.

2. Hold for **10s** with steady breathing.
3. Rest **2–3 min**.
4. Complete **5 holds**.

## Progression

## Safety
- Stop if you feel sharp pain in the shoulder, elbow, or lower back.

name: Hollow Body Hold
summary: Core stiffness for tension and efficient movement.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Core stiffness for body tension and efficient movement.

## Setup
- Use a position you can hold with **no joint pain**.
- Keep shoulders engaged and core tight.

## How to do it
1. Get into the target position.
2. Hold for **30s** with steady breathing.
3. Rest **1–1 min**.
4. Complete **3 holds**.

## Progression
- Increase hold time first, then move to a harder progression.

## Safety
- Stop if you feel sharp pain in the shoulder, elbow, or lower back.
cues: Breathe—avoid breath-holding.

name: Hanging Knee Raises
summary: Core and hip flexor strength for toeing-in and steep terrain.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Core + hip flexor strength for toeing-in and steep terrain.

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **8–15**.
- Start from a dead hang; avoid swinging.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **2–2 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 15; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
- If shoulder discomfort, use a captain’s chair or raise knees with smaller ROM.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.
Keep ribs down and core braced.
Shoulders away from ears throughout.
Move smoothly—no bouncing or kipping unless intended.
commonMistakes: Chasing reps with ugly form.

Cutting range of motion as fatigue builds.

name: Hanging Leg Raises
summary: Advanced core control and compression strength.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Advanced core control and compression strength.

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **5–10**.
- Keep legs straight; control the descent.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **2–3 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 10; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
- Avoid aggressive swinging—quality over height.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.
Keep ribs down and core braced.

name: Campus Board Ladders
summary: Powerful contact strength; keep volume low.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Contact strength + pulling power on the campus board (advanced).

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **1–2**.
- One ‘rep’ = one ladder up (e.g., 1-3-5) with controlled catch.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **3–3 min** between sets.
4. Complete **6 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 2; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
- Only when fingers are healthy and warm; keep volume very low.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.
Keep ribs down and core braced.
Shoulders away from ears throughout.
Move smoothly—no bouncing or kipping unless intended.
Catch with slightly bent elbows; absorb force through shoulders.
Keep feet off only if it’s safe; otherwise use feet-on progressions.
commonMistakes: Chasing reps with ugly form.
Letting shoulders roll forward at the top/bottom.
Cutting range of motion as fatigue builds.
Not resting enough to keep reps high quality.
Too much volume (common cause of finger/elbow flare-ups).
Launching from cold fingers or after a high-volume session.

name: Campus Double Dynos
summary: Explosive recruitment and coordination; advanced only.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Develop explosive contact strength and coordination with **double dynos** (advanced only).

## Setup
- Use large, comfortable rungs; start feet-on if needed.
- Warm up fingers and shoulders thoroughly.
- Keep attempts low and high quality.

## How to do it
1. Start matched on a rung.
2. Generate force through shoulders and lats; jump both hands to the target rung.
3. Stick the catch with control (no “slam and hope”).
4. Rest fully between attempts.

## Progression
- Increase rung spacing only when catches stay crisp and pain-free.

## Safety
- Avoid if you have any finger, elbow, or shoulder niggles.
cues: Explode then ‘catch softly’—absorb force through shoulders.
Keep core tight to reduce swing on the catch.
Stop when contact quality drops.
Prefer bigger rungs over bigger spacing at first.
commonMistakes: Doing dynos on small rungs (excess finger shock load).
Too many attempts and getting sloppy.
Catching with straight locked elbows (joint stress).
Dynoing when fatigued from hard bouldering.

name: Plyometric Pull-Ups
summary: Upper-body power for big moves; low volume.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Build upper-body power for big moves by training explosive pull-ups (low volume).

## Setup
- Use a stable bar; chalk if needed.
- Warm up shoulders/elbows with scap pull-ups and easy pull-ups.

## How to do it
1. From a dead hang, pull explosively so the bar reaches mid-chest or higher.
2. Pause briefly at the top (avoid slamming).
3. Lower under control.
4. Rest fully between sets.

## Progression
- Increase height first, then add small external load.

## Safety
- Stop if you feel elbow tendon irritation; keep reps very crisp.
cues: Explode up; control down.
Keep ribs down and core tight to limit swing.
Finish with shoulders depressed (not shrugged).
Quality > quantity—stop before speed drops.
commonMistakes: Turning it into kipping pull-ups unintentionally.
Too many reps leading to sloppy landings/descents.
Relying on momentum instead of pulling power.
Training plyometrics when elbows are already cranky.

name: Limit Bouldering Session
summary: Max intensity bouldering attempts with long rests.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Improve maximal bouldering ability by taking **high-quality attempts** near your limit with long rests.

## Setup
- Choose 3–6 problems around your current limit (or slightly above).
- Keep total hard attempts controlled to protect fingers/skin.
- Use a timer for rests.

## How to do it
1. Attempt a problem for up to ~1–2 minutes of real effort.
2. Rest **3–5 minutes** between attempts (longer if power isn’t back).
3. Rotate between problems; stop when quality drops.

## Progression
- Track: best move reached, number of quality attempts, and sends.
- Progress by improving density of quality attempts, not by shortening rest.

## Safety
- End early if fingers feel tweaky or skin is near failure.
cues: Take full rests; treat each attempt like a max lift.
Video a few tries to spot technique inefficiencies.
Stop before you start ‘thrashing’.
Keep shoulders engaged on steep moves.
commonMistakes: Resting too little and turning it into power-endurance.
Spamming one move until skin/fingers are cooked.
Picking too many problems and never getting quality attempts.
Ignoring early warning signs in fingers/pulleys.

name: Board Climbing (Limit)
summary: Short, powerful board problems; strict rest discipline.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Develop limit strength/power on a board (Moon/Kilter/Tension) with strict rest discipline.

## Setup
- Pick 3–5 problems with hard moves but safe landings.
- Board climbing is finger-dense; keep total volume low.

## How to do it
1. Take a max attempt (1–2 minutes of effort).
2. Rest **3–5 minutes**.
3. Rotate problems; cap the number of hard attempts.

## Progression
- Add attempts only if quality stays high, or choose slightly harder problems.

## Safety
- Avoid if fingers are sore; board style is high intensity.
cues: Full rest or it isn’t ‘limit’ board climbing.
Keep feet precise—avoid cutting and swinging wildly.
Pull with the back; don’t ‘arm yank’ on edges.
Stop if fingers feel unstable.
commonMistakes: Doing too much volume on small edges.
Resting too little and getting pumped.
Continuing once skin is gone (changes movement and increases injury risk).
Sessioning tweaky grips (e.g., hard half-crimp) when fatigued.

name: 4x4s (Bouldering)
summary: Power endurance staple: 4 problems x 4 rounds with controlled rest.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Build bouldering **power endurance** by accumulating short bursts of hard climbing with incomplete rest.

## Setup
- Choose **4 boulders** around ~2–4 grades below your max (you should be able to do each when fresh).
- Decide a rest between problems (typically **30–60s**).

## How to do it
1. Climb boulder #1 → rest briefly → #2 → #3 → #4 (that’s 1 round).
2. Rest **4 minutes** between rounds.
3. Complete **4 rounds**.

## Progression
- Reduce rest between problems slightly, or choose slightly harder boulders.

## Safety
- Stop if you’re getting “flaily” or landing poorly—fatigue increases fall risk.
cues: Keep rests strict—use a timer.
Focus on efficient movement; avoid thrashing.
Shake out arms during rests.
Choose boulders with safe falls.
commonMistakes: Choosing boulders too hard and failing early each round.
Taking long rests between problems and losing the PE stimulus.
Ignoring skin/finger fatigue and forcing volume.
Doing 4x4s too often (recovery cost is high).

name: 3x3s (Bouldering)
summary: Reduced-volume power endurance intervals; easier to recover from than 4x4s.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
A lower-volume power endurance interval session (easier to recover from than 4x4s).

## Setup
- Choose **3 boulders** ~2–4 grades below max.
- Use **30–60s** rest between problems.

## How to do it
1. Climb #1 → rest → #2 → rest → #3 (1 round).
2. Rest **3 minutes** between rounds.
3. Complete **3 rounds**.

## Progression
- Add a round (to 4), or slightly reduce intra-round rests.

## Safety
- Keep landings controlled; stop if coordination deteriorates.
cues: Keep difficulty moderate—quality reps matter.
Use controlled breathing to manage pump.
Stay smooth and quiet with feet.
Stick to the rest plan.
commonMistakes: Picking problems that are too hard or too pumpy.
Cutting rest between rounds too short.
Letting technique collapse under fatigue.
Adding volume too quickly week-to-week.

name: Linked Boulder Circuits
summary: Link multiple easier boulders for sustained effort.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Build sustained bouldering capacity by linking multiple easier problems into longer efforts.

## Setup
- Pick 2–4 easy boulders that flow well together.
- Plan the link (order, downclimb, traverse).

## How to do it
1. Complete the planned link (1 ‘rep’).
2. Rest **2 minutes**.
3. Repeat for **6 reps** (or stop when quality drops).

## Progression
- Add one boulder to the link, or reduce rest slightly.

## Safety
- Manage skin: links can sneakily accumulate lots of moves.
cues: Stay relaxed; keep arms straight where possible.
Keep feet precise as fatigue rises.
Use shakeouts mid-link if available.
Keep rest consistent.
commonMistakes: Choosing boulders too hard and failing the link repeatedly.
Rushing rests and turning it into a suffer-fest.
Ignoring skin and getting splits.
Poor route planning leading to unsafe falls.

name: ARC (Continuous Easy Climbing)
summary: Aerobic capacity: long easy continuous climbing with low pump.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Improve aerobic capacity (ARC) with long, easy continuous climbing at low pump.

## Setup
- Choose very easy terrain: ~no harder than a pace where you can maintain a conversation.
- Prefer long traverses, auto-belay laps, or very easy routes.

## How to do it
1. Climb continuously for **20 minutes** keeping pump at ~2–3/10.
2. Rest **5 minutes** (shake out, hydrate).
3. Repeat for a second 20-minute block.

## Progression
- Extend block length (to 25–30 min) before increasing difficulty.

## Safety
- Stop if elbows/shoulders become painful; ARC should feel easy.
cues: You should feel warm, not pumped out.
Keep hands relaxed; avoid death-gripping.
Use straight arms and good hips-in positions.
Breathe steadily the entire time.
commonMistakes: Climbing too hard and turning ARC into threshold training.
Stopping frequently instead of keeping continuous movement.
Overgripping due to poor footwork.
Skipping hydration on longer blocks.

name: Route Intervals (2 x 15 min blocks)
summary: Sustained endurance blocks on routes or autobelay circuits.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Build sustained endurance with two longer climbing blocks.

## Setup
- Use routes/auto-belay laps that keep you working but not failing constantly.
- Plan how you’ll keep moving (lap routes, climb-downs, traverses).

## How to do it
1. Climb continuously for **15 minutes** (steady work; brief shakes ok).
2. Rest **5 minutes**.
3. Repeat for a second 15-minute block.

## Progression
- Increase to 2x18–20 minutes, or slightly increase route difficulty.

## Safety
- Keep it controlled; stop before you get reckless with clipping/footwork.
cues: Find shakeouts early and use them.
Focus on relaxed grip and straight arms.
Keep pace steady—avoid sprinting then stopping.
Use efficient clipping positions if on ropes.
commonMistakes: Choosing routes too hard and failing repeatedly.
Racing the first block and blowing up.
Ignoring technique and just ‘surviving’.
Not resting long enough between blocks.

name: Power Endurance (30s on / 30s off)
summary: Short hard intervals (on wall or circuit) to build PE.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Improve power endurance with short hard intervals (on a wall circuit or board).

## Setup
- Choose a circuit that feels **hard** but repeatable for multiple reps.
- You should be close to pumped by the end, but still moving well.

## How to do it
1. Climb for **30s**.
2. Rest for **30s**.
3. Repeat for **10 reps**.
4. Rest **5 minutes** and repeat for a second set if quality remains.

## Progression
- Add a rep or set, or slightly increase circuit difficulty.

## Safety
- High pump increases fall risk; choose safe terrain and downclimb where possible.
cues: Use the clock—start and stop exactly on time.
Keep feet active; don’t overgrip.
Shake out during rests.
Stop the set when movement becomes unsafe.
commonMistakes: Picking a circuit that’s too hard and failing early.
Skipping rests or extending rests inconsistently.
Letting technique collapse as pump rises.
Doing 30/30s too close to heavy finger sessions.

name: Silent Feet Drill
summary: Technique drill to improve foot placement precision.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Improve foot placement precision by placing each foot silently and deliberately.

## Setup
- Pick very easy terrain (you should be able to talk while climbing).
- Decide the one thing you’re focusing on for the set (e.g. silent feet).

## How to do it
1. Perform **4 climbs/laps** focusing on the drill constraint.
2. Rest **2–2 min**.
3. Repeat for **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Keep difficulty easy; progress by improving precision/consistency, not by going harder.

## Safety
- Stay well within your limit; drills are about skill, not strain.
cues: Go easy enough that you can execute perfectly.
One focus at a time—don’t multitask cues.
Slow down at cruxy foot placements.
Review what went well after each lap.
commonMistakes: Choosing terrain that’s too hard and losing the drill quality.
Rushing and turning it into cardio.
Ignoring body position and overgripping.
Doing so much volume that skin/fingers become the limiter.

name: Downclimbing Drill
summary: Builds control and movement efficiency; great warm-up.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Improve control and movement efficiency by downclimbing with the same precision as upclimbing.

## Setup
- Pick very easy terrain (you should be able to talk while climbing).
- Decide the one thing you’re focusing on for the set (e.g. silent feet).

## How to do it
1. Perform **4 climbs/laps** focusing on the drill constraint.
2. Rest **2–2 min**.
3. Repeat for **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Keep difficulty easy; progress by improving precision/consistency, not by going harder.

## Safety
- Stay well within your limit; drills are about skill, not strain.
cues: Go easy enough that you can execute perfectly.
One focus at a time—don’t multitask cues.
Slow down at cruxy foot placements.
Review what went well after each lap.
commonMistakes: Choosing terrain that’s too hard and losing the drill quality.
Rushing and turning it into cardio.
Ignoring body position and overgripping.
Doing so much volume that skin/fingers become the limiter.

name: Flagging Drill
summary: Practice flagging to improve balance and reduce arm load.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Practice flagging to improve balance, reduce arm load, and keep hips close to the wall.

## Setup
- Pick very easy terrain (you should be able to talk while climbing).
- Decide the one thing you’re focusing on for the set (e.g. silent feet).

## How to do it
1. Perform **4 climbs/laps** focusing on the drill constraint.
2. Rest **2–2 min**.
3. Repeat for **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Keep difficulty easy; progress by improving precision/consistency, not by going harder.

## Safety
- Stay well within your limit; drills are about skill, not strain.
cues: Go easy enough that you can execute perfectly.
One focus at a time—don’t multitask cues.
Slow down at cruxy foot placements.
Review what went well after each lap.
commonMistakes: Choosing terrain that’s too hard and losing the drill quality.
Rushing and turning it into cardio.
Ignoring body position and overgripping.
Doing so much volume that skin/fingers become the limiter.

name: Hip Turn / Drop-Knee Drill
summary: Efficient hip positioning to extend reach and conserve energy.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Practice hip turns/drop-knees to extend reach and conserve energy.

## Setup
- Pick very easy terrain (you should be able to talk while climbing).
- Decide the one thing you’re focusing on for the set (e.g. silent feet).

## How to do it
1. Perform **3 climbs/laps** focusing on the drill constraint.
2. Rest **2–3 min**.
3. Repeat for **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Keep difficulty easy; progress by improving precision/consistency, not by going harder.

## Safety
- Stay well within your limit; drills are about skill, not strain.
cues: Go easy enough that you can execute perfectly.
One focus at a time—don’t multitask cues.
Slow down at cruxy foot placements.
Review what went well after each lap.
commonMistakes: Choosing terrain that’s too hard and losing the drill quality.
Rushing and turning it into cardio.
Ignoring body position and overgripping.
Doing so much volume that skin/fingers become the limiter.

name: Straight-Arm Climbing Drill
summary: Teaches relaxed positions and efficient skeletal stacking.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Learn relaxed positions and skeletal stacking by keeping arms straight whenever possible.

## Setup
- Pick very easy terrain (you should be able to talk while climbing).
- Decide the one thing you’re focusing on for the set (e.g. silent feet).

## How to do it
1. Perform **4 climbs/laps** focusing on the drill constraint.
2. Rest **2–2 min**.
3. Repeat for **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Keep difficulty easy; progress by improving precision/consistency, not by going harder.

## Safety
- Stay well within your limit; drills are about skill, not strain.
cues: Go easy enough that you can execute perfectly.
One focus at a time—don’t multitask cues.
Slow down at cruxy foot placements.
Review what went well after each lap.
commonMistakes: Choosing terrain that’s too hard and losing the drill quality.
Rushing and turning it into cardio.
Ignoring body position and overgripping.
Doing so much volume that skin/fingers become the limiter.

name: Foot Swap Drill
summary: Practice controlled foot swaps on small footholds.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Practice controlled foot swaps on small footholds with stable hips.

## Setup
- Pick very easy terrain (you should be able to talk while climbing).
- Decide the one thing you’re focusing on for the set (e.g. silent feet).

## How to do it
1. Perform **3 climbs/laps** focusing on the drill constraint.
2. Rest **2–3 min**.
3. Repeat for **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Keep difficulty easy; progress by improving precision/consistency, not by going harder.

## Safety
- Stay well within your limit; drills are about skill, not strain.
cues: Go easy enough that you can execute perfectly.
One focus at a time—don’t multitask cues.
Slow down at cruxy foot placements.
Review what went well after each lap.
commonMistakes: Choosing terrain that’s too hard and losing the drill quality.
Rushing and turning it into cardio.
Ignoring body position and overgripping.
Doing so much volume that skin/fingers become the limiter.

name: Push-Ups
summary: Antagonist pushing strength for shoulder balance.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Antagonist pushing strength to balance heavy pulling volume.

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **8–20**.
- Elevate hands for easier; elevate feet or add weight for harder.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **1–2 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 20; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.
Keep ribs down and core braced.
Shoulders away from ears throughout.
Move smoothly—no bouncing or kipping unless intended.
commonMistakes: Chasing reps with ugly form.
Letting shoulders roll forward at the top/bottom.
Cutting range of motion as fatigue builds.
Not resting enough to keep reps high quality.

name: Dips
summary: Chest/triceps antagonist work; scale as needed.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Antagonist chest/triceps strength; supports shoulder balance.

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **5–10**.
- Use bars/rings; scale with assistance if needed.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **2–3 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 10; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
- Keep shoulders depressed; avoid painful deep range.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.
Keep ribs down and core braced.
Shoulders away from ears throughout.
Move smoothly—no bouncing or kipping unless intended.
commonMistakes: Chasing reps with ugly form.
Letting shoulders roll forward at the top/bottom.
Cutting range of motion as fatigue builds.
Not resting enough to keep reps high quality.

name: Band External Rotations
summary: Rotator cuff prehab to support high pulling volume.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Rotator cuff endurance/strength for shoulder stability.

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **12–20**.
- Elbow at side; rotate from shoulder, not wrist.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **1–1 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 20; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
- Stay light—this should never feel like a max effort.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.
Keep ribs down and core braced.
Shoulders away from ears throughout.
Move smoothly—no bouncing or kipping unless intended.
commonMistakes: Chasing reps with ugly form.
Letting shoulders roll forward at the top/bottom.
Cutting range of motion as fatigue builds.
Not resting enough to keep reps high quality.

name: Face Pulls
summary: Upper back + rear delts for shoulder stability.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Upper back + rear delts for scapular stability and posture.

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **12–20**.
- Band or cable at face height; finish with thumbs back.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **1–2 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 20; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.
Keep ribs down and core braced.
Shoulders away from ears throughout.
Move smoothly—no bouncing or kipping unless intended.
commonMistakes: Chasing reps with ugly form.
Letting shoulders roll forward at the top/bottom.
Cutting range of motion as fatigue builds.
Not resting enough to keep reps high quality.

name: Wrist Extensor Curls
summary: Forearm extensor strength to balance gripping.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Forearm extensor strength to balance gripping and support elbow health.

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **15–25**.
- Light dumbbell; support forearm on thigh/bench.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **1–1 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 25; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.
Keep ribs down and core braced.
Shoulders away from ears throughout.
Move smoothly—no bouncing or kipping unless intended.
commonMistakes: Chasing reps with ugly form.
Letting shoulders roll forward at the top/bottom.
Cutting range of motion as fatigue builds.
Not resting enough to keep reps high quality.

name: Reverse Flys
summary: Rear delts/scapular control to support pulling posture.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Rear delts/scapular control to support pulling posture.

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **12–20**.
- Use light DBs or band; pause at end range.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **1–2 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 20; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.
Keep ribs down and core braced.
Shoulders away from ears throughout.
Move smoothly—no bouncing or kipping unless intended.
commonMistakes: Chasing reps with ugly form.
Letting shoulders roll forward at the top/bottom.
Cutting range of motion as fatigue builds.
Not resting enough to keep reps high quality.

name: Thoracic Rotations
summary: Mobility for better overhead positions and twisting.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Improve thoracic spine rotation for better overhead positions and twisting movements on the wall.

## Setup
- Use a comfortable kneeling or side-lying position.
- Move slowly; avoid forcing range.

## How to do it
1. Rotate through your upper back while keeping hips relatively stable.
2. Exhale as you rotate to encourage range.
3. Do **8 reps per side** for **2–3 sets**.

## Progression
- Increase range and control, not speed.

## Safety
- Stop if you feel sharp pain or pinching in the spine/shoulder.
cues: Move from the upper back, not the lower back.
Exhale into the rotation.
Keep shoulders relaxed.
Control the return.
commonMistakes: Forcing range and arching lower back.
Moving too fast and losing control.
Letting hips spin instead of the thoracic spine.
Holding breath.

name: Shoulder Dislocates (Band)
summary: Shoulder mobility and control; keep it pain-free.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Improve shoulder mobility and control through a pain-free overhead range.

## Setup
- Use a light band or PVC; start with a wide grip.
- Keep ribs down to avoid compensating with the lower back.

## How to do it
1. With straight arms, raise the band overhead and continue behind you.
2. Reverse back to the start.
3. Perform **10 reps** for **2 sets**.

## Progression
- Narrow grip slightly over time (only if pain-free).

## Safety
- No pinching; reduce range or widen grip immediately if you feel discomfort.
cues: Straight elbows; move slowly.
Ribs down, glutes lightly on.
Keep shoulders ‘packed’ not shrugged.
Use the widest grip that is pain-free.
commonMistakes: Too narrow grip causing shoulder pinching.
Bending elbows to cheat range.
Overarching lower back.
Going fast and losing control.

name: Wrist Mobility Routine
summary: Wrist prep for mantles, slopers, and compression.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Prepare wrists for mantles, slopers, and compression by moving through common wrist ranges.

## How to do it (pain-free only)
- Wrist circles: 30–60s each direction.
- Palm pulses (kneeling, fingers forward): 10–15 reps.
- Back-of-hand pulses (if tolerated): 8–12 reps.
- Side-to-side ‘rockers’: 10–15 reps.

## Notes
- Keep elbows soft; move slowly and never force end range.

## Safety
- Skip positions that cause sharp pain, tingling, or numbness.
cues: Small range first, then gradually larger.
Even pressure through the hand.
Breathe and relax shoulders.
Stop before sharp pain.
commonMistakes: Forcing end range aggressively.
Locking elbows and dumping load into joints.
Ignoring nerve symptoms (tingling/numbness).
Doing too much volume on irritated wrists.

name: Hip Openers (Climber Routine)
summary: Hip mobility for high-steps and drop knees.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Improve hip mobility for high-steps, drop-knees, and wider stances.

## How to do it
- 90/90 switches: 8 reps per side.
- Deep squat pry: 60s.
- Lunge + hip flexor stretch: 45s per side.
- Pigeon (or figure-4): 45s per side.

## Notes
- Move slowly and breathe; prioritize control over depth.

## Safety
- Avoid sharp pinching in the front of the hip; reduce range or change angle.
cues: Slow transitions; control the end positions.
Breathe into tight areas.
Keep pelvis neutral—don’t crank the lower back.
Aim for symmetry left/right over time.
commonMistakes: Forcing range and causing hip pinching.
Rushing through holds.
Letting knees collapse inward.
Ignoring discomfort that lingers after the session.

name: Compression Hold (Seated Pike / L-Sit Progression)
summary: Compression strength for steep climbing and heel hooks.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Compression strength for steep climbing, heel hooks, and toeing-in (pike/L-sit progression).

## Setup
- Use a position you can hold with **no joint pain**.
- Keep shoulders engaged and core tight.

## How to do it
1. Get into the target position.
2. Hold for **15s** with steady breathing.
3. Rest **1–2 min**.
4. Complete **5 holds**.

## Progression
- Increase hold time first, then move to a harder progression.

## Safety
- Stop if you feel sharp pain in the shoulder, elbow, or lower back.
cues: Breathe—avoid breath-holding.
Maintain body tension (ribs down, glutes on).
Keep shoulder blades engaged and stable.
Stop the set before you lose the shape.
commonMistakes: Overarching lower back to ‘fake’ the position.
Shrugging into shoulders during fatigue.
Holding too long and turning it into a sloppy grind.
Progressing too quickly to harder variations.

name: Climbing Warm-Up (Easy Boulders)
summary: Progressive warm-up ladder on easy climbs.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
A progressive climbing warm-up that prepares fingers, shoulders, and movement patterns.

## Setup
- Start very easy and increase difficulty gradually.
- Include different hold types and angles if possible.

## How to do it
1. Do 3–5 very easy boulders (focus on smooth movement).
2. Do 2–3 easy-moderate boulders (slightly higher effort).
3. Do 1–2 ‘primer’ boulders (short, snappy, not max) before your main session.

## Notes
- Rest briefly between climbs; avoid getting pumped in the warm-up.

## Safety
- If fingers feel stiff, extend the easy phase rather than jumping grades.
cues: Start easier than you think.
Move quietly and deliberately.
Engage shoulders early; avoid dead-hanging cold.
Stop warm-up before you’re pumped.
commonMistakes: Jumping straight onto small edges.
Doing too many hard tries in warm-up.
Ignoring shoulder activation (scapular control).
Rushing because you ‘feel fine’—fingers lag behind.

name: Footwork-Only Lap (Hands Light)
summary: Technique endurance; focus on feet and posture.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Improve movement efficiency by making feet do the work while keeping hands light.

## Setup
- Choose very easy terrain (route or long traverse).
- Use open hands; avoid crimping.

## How to do it
1. Climb a lap focusing on: high-steps, precise placement, and hips close to the wall.
2. Keep hands ‘for balance’—if forearms are working hard, go easier.
3. Rest 2 minutes and repeat for 4–6 laps.

## Progression
- Increase lap length or reduce rest; keep intensity easy.

## Safety
- Avoid slippery feet or sketchy dynos; this is about control.
cues: Push through legs; stay tall.
Soft hands—don’t squeeze.
Hips in; move one limb at a time.
Feet: place then weight; no tapping.
commonMistakes: Choosing terrain too hard and pulling with arms.
Rushing and losing precision.
Letting core go slack and barn-dooring.
Doing too much volume and shredding skin.

name: Dead Hangs (Jugs)
summary: Low-intensity hanging for warm-up and shoulder conditioning.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Low-intensity hanging to warm up shoulders and condition passive structures.

## Setup
- Use comfortable jugs (no finger strain).
- Engage shoulders gently; avoid full ‘dead’ shrug.

## How to do it
1. Hang for **30 seconds** with shoulders lightly engaged.
2. Rest **60 seconds**.
3. Repeat for **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Increase time slightly or add scap retractions during the hang.

## Safety
- Stop if you feel shoulder pinching or numbness/tingling in hands.
cues: Long body line; ribs stacked.
Shoulders gently down/back.
Relax grip; jugs should feel easy.
Breathe steadily.
commonMistakes: Hanging with shoulders fully shrugged.
Using holds that strain fingers.
Swinging or twisting.
Ignoring shoulder discomfort.

name: Pinch Block Lifts
summary: Pinch grip strength for pinch-heavy styles/problems.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Improve pinch strength for pinch-heavy problems and sloper/pinch combinations.

## Setup
- Use a pinch block and loading pin (or adjustable weight).
- Choose a load you can lift smoothly without pain.

## How to do it
1. Stand tall, shoulders packed, arm straight.
2. Lift the weight for **3–5 seconds**, then lower under control.
3. Perform **5 reps per hand** for **3 sets**, resting **2–3 min** between sets.

## Progression
- Add small weight increments or increase hold time.

## Safety
- Keep wrist neutral; stop if you feel sharp finger or thumb pain.
cues: Drive through thumb pad and fingers evenly.
Shoulder packed; no shrugging.
Lift smoothly—no jerks.
Neutral wrist; don’t ‘curl’ the block.
commonMistakes: Jerking the lift off the floor.
Bending elbow and turning it into a curl.
Letting wrist collapse into flexion.
Too much weight causing thumb joint irritation.

name: Wrist Roller
summary: Forearm endurance/strength; useful for sustained gripping.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Forearm endurance/strength via continuous wrist flexion/extension rolling.

## Setup
- Use a wrist roller with a moderate load.
- Keep elbows slightly bent and shoulders down/back.

## How to do it
1. Roll weight up until the cord is fully wound.
2. Roll back down under control.
3. That is 1 rep. Do **3 reps** for **3 sets**, resting **2 min**.

## Progression
- Add small weight or extra up/down cycles.

## Safety
- Stop if you feel sharp elbow pain; keep it moderate.
cues: Smooth roll—no ‘yanking’ with shoulders.
Wrists do the work; keep arms quiet.
Control the descent.
Moderate load you can repeat.
commonMistakes: Too heavy and compensating with body swing.
Letting shoulders shrug up.
Dropping the weight quickly on the way down.
Doing it to failure and flaring elbows.

name: Calf Raises (Foot Strength Support)
summary: Supports foot/ankle resilience for edging and high volume.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Foot/ankle strength and resilience for edging and high volume.

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **12–25**.
- Use a step for full range; add weight for harder.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **1–1 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 25; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.
Keep ribs down and core braced.
Shoulders away from ears throughout.
Move smoothly—no bouncing or kipping unless intended.
commonMistakes: Chasing reps with ugly form.
Letting shoulders roll forward at the top/bottom.
Cutting range of motion as fatigue builds.
Not resting enough to keep reps high quality.

name: Single-Leg RDL
summary: Posterior chain + balance; helps with body tension and injury resilience.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Posterior chain + balance; supports body tension and injury resilience.

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **6–12**.
- Hold a DB in opposite hand; keep hips square.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **2–2 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 12; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.
Keep ribs down and core braced.
Shoulders away from ears throughout.
Move smoothly—no bouncing or kipping unless intended.
commonMistakes: Chasing reps with ugly form.
Letting shoulders roll forward at the top/bottom.
Cutting range of motion as fatigue builds.
Not resting enough to keep reps high quality.

name: Step-Ups
summary: Leg strength for high-steps and overall conditioning.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Leg strength for high-steps and overall conditioning.

## Setup
- Choose a variation/load that keeps reps **clean** within **8–15**.
- Use a box height that challenges but stays controlled; add load as needed.

## How to do it
1. Perform controlled reps through a full, pain-free range.
2. Stop **1–2 reps before form breaks**.
3. Rest **1–2 min** between sets.
4. Complete **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Add reps up to 15; then increase load or make the variation harder.

## Safety
- Keep shoulders packed and wrists neutral.
cues: Control the lowering phase; don’t drop into end range.
Keep ribs down and core braced.
Shoulders away from ears throughout.
Move smoothly—no bouncing or kipping unless intended.
commonMistakes: Chasing reps with ugly form.
Letting shoulders roll forward at the top/bottom.
Cutting range of motion as fatigue builds.
Not resting enough to keep reps high quality.

name: Heel Hook Tension Drill
summary: Practice heel engagement and hip positioning on easier terrain.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Practice heel engagement + hip position while maintaining core tension.

## Setup
- Pick very easy terrain (you should be able to talk while climbing).
- Decide the one thing you’re focusing on for the set (e.g. silent feet).

## How to do it
1. Perform **3 climbs/laps** focusing on the drill constraint.
2. Rest **2–3 min**.
3. Repeat for **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Keep difficulty easy; progress by improving precision/consistency, not by going harder.

## Safety
- Stay well within your limit; drills are about skill, not strain.
cues: Go easy enough that you can execute perfectly.
One focus at a time—don’t multitask cues.
Slow down at cruxy foot placements.
Review what went well after each lap.
commonMistakes: Choosing terrain that’s too hard and losing the drill quality.
Rushing and turning it into cardio.
Ignoring body position and overgripping.
Doing so much volume that skin/fingers become the limiter.

name: Toe Hook Drill
summary: Practice toe hooks and core tension on steep features.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Practice toe hooks with core tension and controlled body position on steep features.

## Setup
- Pick very easy terrain (you should be able to talk while climbing).
- Decide the one thing you’re focusing on for the set (e.g. silent feet).

## How to do it
1. Perform **3 climbs/laps** focusing on the drill constraint.
2. Rest **2–3 min**.
3. Repeat for **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Keep difficulty easy; progress by improving precision/consistency, not by going harder.

## Safety
- Stay well within your limit; drills are about skill, not strain.
cues: Go easy enough that you can execute perfectly.
One focus at a time—don’t multitask cues.
Slow down at cruxy foot placements.
Review what went well after each lap.
commonMistakes: Choosing terrain that’s too hard and losing the drill quality.
Rushing and turning it into cardio.
Ignoring body position and overgripping.
Doing so much volume that skin/fingers become the limiter.

name: Mantle Progressions
summary: Top-out/mantle skill progressions (indoors or on slabs).
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Build top-out/mantle skill: weight transfer over hands with controlled wrist/shoulder positions.

## Setup
- Pick very easy terrain (you should be able to talk while climbing).
- Decide the one thing you’re focusing on for the set (e.g. silent feet).

## How to do it
1. Perform **3 climbs/laps** focusing on the drill constraint.
2. Rest **2–3 min**.
3. Repeat for **4 sets**.

## Progression
- Keep difficulty easy; progress by improving precision/consistency, not by going harder.

## Safety
- Stay well within your limit; drills are about skill, not strain.
cues: Go easy enough that you can execute perfectly.
One focus at a time—don’t multitask cues.
Slow down at cruxy foot placements.
Review what went well after each lap.
commonMistakes: Choosing terrain that’s too hard and losing the drill quality.
Rushing and turning it into cardio.
Ignoring body position and overgripping.
Doing so much volume that skin/fingers become the limiter.

name: Volume Bouldering (Moderate)
summary: Technique + capacity: many moderate boulders with controlled rest.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Build technique + capacity by doing many moderate boulders with controlled rest.

## Setup
- Pick boulders you can do in 1–3 tries most of the time.
- Aim for variety: slabs, overhangs, different holds.

## How to do it
- Target **12–20 boulders** total (or 45–60 minutes).
- Rest ~**1–2 minutes** between attempts to keep moving quality high.
- Stop if skin or fingers become the limiting factor.

## Progression
- Increase the number of quality climbs, not the difficulty.

## Safety
- Manage skin; avoid continuing once you start slipping due to splits.
cues: Prioritize movement quality over ‘bagging’ volume.
Rest just enough to keep footwork precise.
Pick safe landings; avoid risky dynos when fatigued.
Track total sends/tries for progression.
commonMistakes: Going too hard and turning it into limit bouldering.
Not resting at all and getting sloppy.
Repeating the same style and missing weaknesses.
Ignoring skin/finger fatigue and forcing more volume.

name: Resting Positions Practice
summary: Learn and rehearse no-hands / shake-out rests on routes.
instructionsMarkdown:
## Goal
Rehearse no-hands / shake-out rests: find positions, relax grip, and recover efficiently.

## Setup
- Pick very easy terrain (you should be able to talk while climbing).
- Decide the one thing you’re focusing on for the set (e.g. silent feet).

## How to do it
1. Perform **4 climbs/laps** focusing on the drill constraint.
2. Rest **2–2 min**.
3. Repeat for **3 sets**.

## Progression
- Keep difficulty easy; progress by improving precision/consistency, not by going harder.

## Safety
- Stay well within your limit; drills are about skill, not strain.
cues: Go easy enough that you can execute perfectly.
One focus at a time—don’t multitask cues.
Slow down at cruxy foot placements.
Review what went well after each lap.
commonMistakes: Choosing terrain that’s too hard and losing the drill quality.
Rushing and turning it into cardio.
Ignoring body position and overgripping.
Doing so much volume that skin/fingers become the limiter.
